docs.lead_paragraph: Karilyn Bales, whose husband, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, is accused of killing 16 Afghans, posted about life as a military wife.

headline.seo: Wife of Accused Soldier Kept Blog on Anguish of Army Life
headline.main: Sergeant’s Wife Kept a Blog on the Travails of Army Life
headline.print_headline: Sergeant’s Wife Kept Blog on Woes of Army Life

docs.abstract: Karilyn Bales, wife of Staff Sgt Robert Bales, maintained a blog narrating her struggles, hopes and consolations as a military spouse; blog recounted her pregnancy in Bales' absence, and her subsequent struggles to raise their two children while he was summoned for repeated deployments; much of blog's content was removed after Bales was accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers.
docs.snippet: Karilyn Bales, whose husband, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, is accused of killing 16 Afghans, posted about life as a military wife.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The acclaimed police procedural “Southland” was picked up from NBC by TNT, but it is uncertain if it will endure for another season.

headline.seo: ‘Southland’ With Michael Cudlitz and Regina King on TNT
headline.main: Mortal Cops Cling to Life on the Air
headline.print_headline: Mortal Cops Cling to Life on the Air

docs.abstract: Police show Southland has had trouble finding its spot on television; NBC canceled the gritty drama in 2009 after seven episodes, after which it was picked up by TNT, but it is uncertain if it will endure for another season; show's struggles reflect an increasingly crowded television market in which shows have little time to develop.
docs.snippet: The acclaimed police procedural “Southland” was picked up from NBC by TNT, but it is uncertain if it will endure for another season.

headline.main: You Think You're a Frequent Flyer

docs.abstract: Ron Akana has been a flight attendant at United Airlines for 63 years, logging some 20 million miles, the equivalent of circling the globe 800 times or flying 40 times to the moon and back. Beat that.
docs.snippet: Ron Akana has been a flight attendant at United Airlines for 63 years, logging some 20 million miles, the equivalent of circling the globe 800 times or flying 40 times to the moon and back. Beat that.

byline.original: By NICOLA CLARK and MARCUS MABRY

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill would allow all employers with religious and moral objections to birth control to refuse to provide insurance coverage for the purpose of avoiding pregnancy.

headline.main: Arizona Might Curb Birth Control Coverage
headline.print_headline: Arizona Might Curb Birth Control Coverage

docs.abstract: Pending legislation in Arizona will allow all employers with religious and moral objections to refuse to provide coverage for purpose of birth control through their health plans; those employers would still have to provide coverage for contraception drugs for other medical reasons, but could make women seeking reimbursements explain why they need it.
docs.snippet: A bill would allow all employers with religious and moral objections to birth control to refuse to provide insurance coverage for the purpose of avoiding pregnancy.

docs.lead_paragraph: The high-profile prosecution was part of an effort by the Hong Kong government to stanch a surge in mainland Chinese women traveling there to give birth.

headline.main: Hong Kong: Woman Jailed for Role in Helping Pregnant Mainlanders
headline.print_headline: Hong Kong: Woman Jailed for Role In Helping Pregnant Mainlanders

docs.abstract: Chinese woman is sentenced to nine weeks in prison for taking a job with a mainland health care company that involved arranging for at least two other mainland Chinese women to travel to Hong Kong to give birth.
docs.snippet: The high-profile prosecution was part of an effort by the Hong Kong government to stanch a surge in mainland Chinese women traveling there to give birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: Could we all agree that it’s never a good combo when state lawmakers try to deal with the mysteries of human reproduction?
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column excoriates legislation proposed in several states requiring doctors to inform women seeking abortions that the procedure is linked to an increased risk of breast cancer; notes multiple studies that dispel any connection; charges that lawmakers venture into murky waters when they attempt to deal with the mysteries of human reproduction, and the results are generally short of scientific.
docs.snippet: Could we all agree that it’s never a good combo when state lawmakers try to deal with the mysteries of human reproduction?

headline.main: Having Twins With a Surrogate — in India

docs.abstract: I never imagined that my journey to motherhood would involve spending months in a remote Indian village, at the bedside of a woman carrying my fertilized eggs.
docs.snippet: I never imagined that my journey to motherhood would involve spending months in a remote Indian village, at the bedside of a woman carrying my fertilized eggs.

headline.main: Solving Problems: Hiring, Visiting Competitors, an Old Web Site

docs.abstract: Getting reader advice on what happens when a business hires its 15th employee.
docs.snippet: Getting reader advice on what happens when a business hires its 15th employee.

headline.main: Quandary Considered: Pregnant, With a Job Interview

docs.abstract: Should the pregnant job applicant tell all? Readers, who've been on both sides of the interview table, say no.
docs.snippet: Should the pregnant job applicant tell all? Readers, who've been on both sides of the interview table, say no.

docs.lead_paragraph: The annual Pap smear, a cornerstone of women's health for at least 60 years, is now officially a thing of the past, as new national guidelines recommend cervical cancer screening no more often than every three years. In recent years, some doctors and medical groups, including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in 2009, began urging less frequent screening for cervical cancer. Even so, annual Pap smear testing is still common because many women are reluctant to give up frequent screening for cervical cancer.

headline.main: New Pap Smear Guidelines Advise Less Frequent Tests

docs.abstract: United States Preventive Services Task Force issues new Pap test guidelines that advise women to undergo cervical cancer screening no more than every three years; in addition, women are advised to begin screening at age 21, regardless of sexual history, and to no longer be tested after age 65, as long as they have had adequate prior screenings and are not otherwise at high risk for cervical cancer. (M)
